docs.snippet: Latin American officials met for a second day Sunday in an effort to end an impasse in negotiations on a regional peace treaty for Central America. The talks continued unexpectedly into the early morning hours with no decisions anticipated until...
docs.lead_paragraph: Latin American officials met for a second day Sunday in an effort to end an impasse in negotiations on a regional peace treaty for Central America. The talks continued unexpectedly into the early morning hours with no decisions anticipated until later today. The weekend discussions, involving Foreign Ministers from five Central American nations and from eight countries involved in what is known as the Contadora peace process, centered on security guarantees and on United States assistance to Nicaraguan rebels, according to several negotiators. Officials said Nicaragua was demanding that the Contadora group condemn the Reagan Administration's effort to provide new funds to the Nicaraguan rebels and that the negotiators call for direct talks between the United States and Nicaragua.

headline.main: NEGOTIATORS TRY TO END IMPASSE ON A CENTRAL AMERICA TREATY

byline.original: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: ''For the past two years, we feel we have been pushing a very heavy load up a very steep hill,'' Christian Knaust said. ''But now we have a feeling that it's finally happening, people are beginning to know we are here,'' said Kenth Andersson, his...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''For the past two years, we feel we have been pushing a very heavy load up a very steep hill,'' Christian Knaust said. ''But now we have a feeling that it's finally happening, people are beginning to know we are here,'' said Kenth Andersson, his partner and codesigner in the company they call Christian Kenth. The two - Mr. Knaust is 36 years old and Mr. Andersson 42 - are among the promising new faces who will be showing their new collections when the New York fall and winter fashion showings open at the end of this month. What they all have in common is the belief that they have something fresh to offer, a new slant on how women can dress. Each hopes to make it into the big time.

headline.main: IN FASHION, SOME PROMISING NEW TALENT

docs.snippet: After three days of at times heated discussions, negotiations to find a settlement to the conflicts of Central America broke up here this afternoon in a cloud of recriminations without any formal agreements being reached.   In a disappointing end to...
docs.lead_paragraph: After three days of at times heated discussions, negotiations to find a settlement to the conflicts of Central America broke up here this afternoon in a cloud of recriminations without any formal agreements being reached. In a disappointing end to what had been heralded as a major meeting of the so-called Contadora Group of Latin American countries, a string of Central American foreign ministers left Panama City exchanging condemnations for having failed to achieve concrete results. Representatives from El Salvador, Costa Rica and Honduras blamed Nicaragua for the breakdown in discussions, contending it had torpedoed hopes for peace by failing to sign a compromise agreement obligating all Central American countries to sign a final peace treaty by June 6.

headline.main: LATIN PEACE TALKS END IN WRANGLING

byline.original: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Twenty-two of the world's tallest sailing ships have so far accepted the invitation to lead the parade of ships up the Hudson River on July 4 for the Statue of Liberty centennial.   It will be the largest procession in memory of these majestic,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty-two of the world's tallest sailing ships have so far accepted the invitation to lead the parade of ships up the Hudson River on July 4 for the Statue of Liberty centennial. It will be the largest procession in memory of these majestic, multimasted vessels, with at least six more than the number that took part in New York's Bicentennial celebration in 1976. ''We're giving a party, and we've asked the nations of the world to come to the party,'' Howard Slotnick - director of Operation Sail, which is organizing the event, as it did in 1976 -said at a news conference. ''In 1976, we asked them to come and celebrate our birthday. This year we are asking them here to thank them for what they have done for our nation.''

headline.main: 22 TALL SHIPS ACCEPT BID TO LEAD PARADE ON JULY 4

docs.snippet: Three times world soccer champion and perennial star of the world's most popular sports event, Brazil is bracing itself for disappointment in the quadrennial World Cup tournament that begins May 31 in Mexico.   It is a reaction that runs against the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Three times world soccer champion and perennial star of the world's most popular sports event, Brazil is bracing itself for disappointment in the quadrennial World Cup tournament that begins May 31 in Mexico. It is a reaction that runs against the instinctive optimism of a country where a talent for soccer is acquired as a birthright and where success in the game forms part of the national identity. It is also one that has withstood a fierce barrage of soccer-related television advertising aimed at generating excitement - and profits - before Brazil's 11 best players meet Spain's team in their first-round game June 1. Yet, although Brazilian fans are, as always, ready, willing and able to do their patriotic bit by praying and cheering, crying and dancing, there is a problem: The national team has yet to demonstrate that it deserves their support.

headline.main: OUTLOOK IS SHAKY FOR A TRADITIONAL SOCCER POWER

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: With 4,300 miles to go, the United States maxiyacht Atlantic Privateer sped past U.B.S. Switzerland today to take the lead in the Whitbread Round-the-World yacht race, organizers said.

headline.main: U.S. YACHT LEADS IN GLOBAL RACE

docs.snippet: President Reagan said tonight that the Nicaraguan Government was seeking to ''build a Libya on our doorstep.''   Mr. Reagan said the Sandinista Government, like that of Libya, ''provided a refuge for all sorts of international terrorists.''   He said...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Reagan said tonight that the Nicaraguan Government was seeking to ''build a Libya on our doorstep.'' Mr. Reagan said the Sandinista Government, like that of Libya, ''provided a refuge for all sorts of international terrorists.'' He said the terrorists included members of the Red Brigades of Italy, the Baader-Meinhof gang of West Germany, the Palestine Liberation Organization and groups from El Salvador, Uruguay and Spain. ''That picture making the rounds showing Daniel Ortega standing with Muammar Qaddafi and raising his fist in a gesture of solidarity is very much to the point,'' Mr. Reagan said in a speech to the Heritage Foundation, a conservative public-policy group. ''I hope every member of Congress will reflect on the fact that the Sandinistas have been training, supporting and directing as well as sheltering terrorists.''

headline.main: REAGAN SAYS SANDINISTAS SEEK TO 'BUILD A LIBYA'

byline.original: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: WHEN the history of 20th-century archeological sculpture is written, Gonzalo Fonseca should have a place in it. His small, excavated, sometimes inhabited slabs of stone are less conceptual than the miniature cities and sites of Anne and Patrick...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the history of 20th-century archeological sculpture is written, Gonzalo Fonseca should have a place in it. His small, excavated, sometimes inhabited slabs of stone are less conceptual than the miniature cities and sites of Anne and Patrick Porier. They do not have the sexual and political edge that Charles Simonds has been trying to build into his erupting mounds. At the age of 64, Fonseca is considerably older than other sculptors involved in some way with ancient places and times. Since he was born in Montevideo, Uruguay, the archeological imagination is rooted in the world he grew up with. His sculpture is something of a search, an attempt to carve and hollow out an artistic stratum where the South America he left in 1950 and the North American and European worlds he has lived in since can join together. The exhibition at the Arnold Herstand Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, through May 31, is the first Fonseca has had in New York since 1971. There are 17 works, which is too many. The theatrical lighting also makes these upright objects on bases look like display cases in Tiffany's. Nevertheless, the strength of the artist's work - as well as his tendency to do a little too much, or to let his work become a bit too finicky - is clear.

docs.snippet: It is at least conceivable that the summit conference this week planted seeds that will change the economy of the world. This is a mixed blessing, for the seven summit leaders planted one seed of harmony and another of discord.   One involves...
docs.lead_paragraph: It is at least conceivable that the summit conference this week planted seeds that will change the economy of the world. This is a mixed blessing, for the seven summit leaders planted one seed of harmony and another of discord. One involves currency rates, and the other trade, especially in farm goods. For the first time in two decades of trying, the biggest industrial democracies settled on a way to corral the excesses of their individual economic policies, especially those that menace everyone else and make the values of currencies go haywire.

byline.original: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The Swiss maxi entry, UBS Switzerland, finished first today in the fourth Whitbread round-the-world yacht race, completing the 27,000-mile event hundreds of miles and at least two days ahead of Cote d'Or of Belgium and Drum of Britain.   The UBS...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Swiss maxi entry, UBS Switzerland, finished first today in the fourth Whitbread round-the-world yacht race, completing the 27,000-mile event hundreds of miles and at least two days ahead of Cote d'Or of Belgium and Drum of Britain. The UBS skipper, Pierre Fehlmann, and his 23-man crew brought the sleek, 79.8-foot yacht across the finish line in this southern English seaport in rainy, cold weather.
